snippet: As 300,000 people learned that their tap water was unsafe, residents and businesses expressed a mix of anger and anxiety in coping with the industrial accident.
abstract: Residents of Charleston, W Va, react with mix of anger and anxiety to finding their tap water is unsafe for use or consumption after industrial accident involving chemicals used in coal processing; Gov Earl Ray Tomblin, who ordered the ban on drinking and using tap water in the capital and nine surrounding counties, calls on people not to panic.

byline.contributor: Timothy Williams and Ashley Southall contributed reporting from New York, and Daniel Heyman from Charleston.

lead_paragraph: As 300,000 people learned that their tap water was unsafe, residents and businesses expressed a mix of anger and anxiety in coping with the industrial accident.

headline.main: Thousands Without Water After Spill in West Virginia
headline.print_headline: Thousands Without Water After Spill in West Virginia
